entry.title: Molasses Cookies
entry.content:
Now that I finally have my mixer parts back from Molly (who had taken great care of them for about a year, after I accidentally left them behind in our old place...haha;;), I am enthusiastic for all matter of baking projects.

In particular, these molasses cookies, which are super chewy and wonderful.

that's a REAL MAPLE LEAF back there! fell the autumn spirit!

The following recipe is from my mother, altered slightly:

(yields 5 dozen)

Ingredients
12 tablespoons butter
1 cup sugar
1 egg
1/4 cup molasses
2 tablespoons evaporated milk or cream
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda
1 tsp. ground cinnamon
1 tsp. ginger
1/4 tsp. ground coriander
1/4 tsp. ground white pepper
1/4 tsp. cayenne pepper
3/4 tsp. salt
3/4 tsp. ground nutmeg (best to grind your own)

Instructions
In a large bowl, cream butter, shortening and sugar, until fluffy/airy. Beat in egg, molasses, milk and vanilla. Combine flour, baking soda, cinnamon, coriander, white pepper, cayenne pepper, salt, and nutmeg; gradually add to creamed mixture. Cover and refrigerate for 1 hour.

Roll into 1 1/4 inch balls. Place 2 inches apart on greased baking sheets. Bake at 350 degrees for 10-14 minutes or until tops crack and edges are slightly firm. Remove to wire racks to cool.

entry.title: Peanut Butter Cupcakes With Honey
entry.content:
I finally had the chance to make cupcakes the other day for the Halloween Sakura-Con staff party!

yum

These are peanut butter and jelly cupcakes from the Martha Stewart cupcake book, which I appreciate for its large, inspiring photos and general ability to strike me with cupcake inspiration every once in a while. Unlike other cupcake books, it contains a variety of recipes, and not just different ways to arrange colored frost for the holidays.

For these cupcakes, I lacked jelly, so instead used some "huckleberry creamed" honey retrieved from a market near Ellensberg.

i think they still tasted fine

I'm not actually a fan of peanut butter sweets, so next time I'll probably go for the tried-and-true (and favorite) Oreo cheesecake cupcakes, or the blackberry cornmeal ones.

entry.title: Bread and Pancakes
entry.content:
On the recommendation of my friend, I checked out Artisan Bread in 5 Minutes a Day from the library and attempted its secrets.

Having never made bread before and heard much of the difficulty of doing so, I was pretty skeptical. In the end it did not, in fact, take me five minutes, but forty or so minutes (from "cloaking" the bread to throwing it in the oven to eating it with delight) is not that bad.

My first attempt was remarkably crusty and white and fluffy inside.

WHOA. did i really do that?

My second attempt was crusted with soot as black as midnight and filled the entire house with smoke besides. But, the inside was still white and fluffy!

and edible!

Another first for me was creating pancakes from a macadamia-nut studded mix. I have to say that I kind of adore the speckled pattern that craters across pancake bottoms, all golden and moony.

now for the syrup

entry.title: Paula Deen's Easy Cheesecake Cupcakes
entry.content:
The other day HC came over and we decided to make cupcakes. Given my limited store of ingredients, we went with cheesecake, that being the type of cupcake that requires little investment in terms of icing and ingredients that I didn't posses.

The recipe is sourced from what I now realize is Kraft's Recipes. We changed the butter extract to vanilla extract. The recipe is for 12 cupcakes, but we ended up making around 18. Also, we ended up not putting any jam or anything on the cupcakes, but they were quite sweet on their own.

Ingredients
  1. 2 pkg. (8 oz. each) cream cheese, softened
  2. 1 cup granulated sugar
  3. 1 tsp. vanilla extract
  4. 2  eggs
  5. 12 vanilla wafers
  6. 1 cup seedless raspberry jam
  7. 1pt. fresh raspberries
  8. 2 tbsp. powdered sugar for dusting

Instructions
  1. Place a paper cupcake liner in each of 18 muffin cups.
  2. Beat cream cheese until fluffy. Add granulated sugar and butter extract, beating well. Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition.
  3. Place a vanilla wafer, flat-side down, in each muffin cup. Spoon cream cheese mixture over wafers, until paper lining is about 3/4ths filled. Bake for 20 minutes.
  4. Allow tarts to cool completely. When cool, top each cheesecake cupcake with 1/2 Tbsp. of raspberry jam and fresh raspberries. Dust with powdered sugar.

Since the vanilla wafers we bought were a little too small for the paper liner, we experimented with making half the liners filled with whole wafers, and half with crushed. (By the way -- vanilla wafers are easily crushed by placing them inside a glass mixing bowl, and mashing them with the flat bottom of another glass.)


In the end, the crushed wafers ended up quite crumbly, so whole wafers really are probably the way to go.

entry.title: Green Tea Cupcakes
entry.content:
mmmmm (pic by heatherchan)

Yesterday Heatherchan came over and we made green tea cupcakes! Also personally known to me as my cupcakes of revenge. Matcha (抹茶) or green tea is a lovely/bitter powdered substance.

i got this matcha from the internet somewhere
(pic by heatherchan)

The cupcakes that I've made with green tea have the matcha flavor without too much bitterness.

warm, not-too-sweet revenge
(pic by heatherchan)

I altered/took the recipe from Taken/altered from a recipe here. It makes a batch of about 24 cupcakes:


Ingredients
  • 1 cup (2 sticks) unsalted butter, room temperature
  • 1 3/4 cups sugar
  • 2 large eggs
  • 2 large egg whites
  • 3 cups all-purpose flour
  • 2 teaspoons baking powder
  • 1/8 teaspoon salt
  • 1 cup milk
  • 2 tablespoons matcha

Instructions
  1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
  2. If you've got your roommate's plastic-rubber cupcake things, you're all set. Else, prepare paper cupcake things by spraying with butter stuff...I guess. (This recipe apparently also makes a cake, so you could butter up a 1/2 pan.)
  3. Put the butter in a mixing bowl. Grab some object from your roommate that looks like it could suffice for mixing. (I use a cake icing spreader, but a spatula will probably work too.) Sit down on the ground, set the bowl between your thighs, and beat furiously. You could think about that ex-whatever that you had (but avoid thinking about how green tea is his favorite flavor...oh). At the end, the butter should be kind of whippy.
  4. Add sugar. Repeat the between-legs beating thing. The mixture should be light and fluffy and could possibly be on your pants and the cuff of your shirt.
  5. Beat two eggs with a fork and add it to the mixture. Walk around the kitchen if you want. Skip some songs on your iPod until you have something sort of fast-paced. (Last Alliance's "Katahiza no Yogore" is good.) By now your arm might be getting kind of tired. Don't worry. Just keep thinking about green tea cupcakes.
  6. Separate the whites from another two eggs, beat the whites with a fork, and add, and mix until...everything's all mixed together. Optional: You might accidentally allow the yolk to bleed into the whites. This is (probably) okay. Add it anyway. Extra note: The initial recipe actually called for two yolks, but I read it as "whites" somehow, so...well...by the time of this writing I've actually made this recipe a couple of times, and it worked both ways, pretty much. Also: Save the yolks for breakfast tomorrow!
  7. Whisk Grab another fork and another bowl and mix together flour, baking powder, and salt in a bowl. Add to batter and mix to combine.
  8. Mix matcha in with the milk. Add to the batter and mix until combine.
  9. Pour into cupcake things, about 3/4 of the way up.
  10. Bake for 22-25 minutes until a cake tester comes out clean.
  11. Remove from baking pans and then put something on them. My favorite topping is cream cheese icing, but this time around we only put more green tea, which had the unfortunate side-effect of making the cupcakes look ominously moldy.
  12. Set on a plate and offer to your roommates. Take a bunch of pictures, pour out some sake, and consume~

Notes:
The green tea flavor in the cake is pretty subtle, so if you like matcha then you could probably get away with adding more. I've tried using a matcha/sugar composite that I found in a store somewhere, but also powdered matcha itself, and they were both pretty good.

cupcake made with pure matcha

cupcake with matcha/sugar mix
